### combineLoadToNewType() {#ad7586c4efa39c8f9162c7608ff9a57cf}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>LoadInst &#42; InstCombinerImpl::combineLoadToNewType (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/loadinst">LoadInst</a> &amp; LI, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/type">Type</a> &#42; NewTy, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> &amp; Suffix=&quot;&quot;)</>}>
Helper to combine a load to a new type.

This just does the work of combining a load to a new type. It handles metadata, etc., and returns the new instruction. The <code>NewTy</code> should be the loaded <em>value</em> type. This will convert it to a pointer, cast the operand to that pointer type, load it, etc.

Note that this will create all of the instructions with whatever insert point the <code><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instcombinerimpl">InstCombinerImpl</a></code> currently is using.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h/#l00197">197</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h">InstCombineInternal.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineloadstorealloca-cpp/#l00548">548</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineloadstorealloca-cpp">InstCombineLoadStoreAlloca.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### dominatesAllUses() {#ad3f2b185fd3e7dd4d0e694e773792fb8}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool InstCombinerImpl::dominatesAllUses (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; DI, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; UI, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/basicblock">BasicBlock</a> &#42; DB) const</>}>
True when DB dominates all uses of DI except UI.

<a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/check">Check</a> that one use is in the same block as the definition and all other uses are in blocks dominated by a given block.

UI must be in the same block as DI. The routine checks that the DI parent and DB are different.

<ParametersListItem name="DI">Definition</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="UI"><a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/use">Use</a></ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="DB">Block that must dominate all uses of <code>DI</code> outside the parent block</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>

<SectionUser title="Returns">
true when <code>UI</code> is the only use of <code>DI</code> in the parent block and all other uses of <code>DI</code> are in blocks dominated by <code>DB</code>.
</SectionUser>

For a binary operator with 2 phi operands, try to hoist the binary operation before the phi.

This can result in fewer instructions in patterns where at least one set of phi operands simplifies. Example: BB3: binop (phi &#91;X, BB1&#93;, &#91;C1, BB2&#93;), (phi &#91;Y, BB1&#93;, &#91;C2, BB2&#93;) --&gt; BB1: BO = binop X, Y BB3: phi &#91;BO, BB1&#93;, &#91;(binop C1, C2), BB2&#93;

### foldCmpLoadFromIndexedGlobal() {#a866883cec7ed781fcf1e9cda18b24f5b}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Instruction &#42; InstCombinerImpl::foldCmpLoadFromIndexedGlobal (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/loadinst">LoadInst</a> &#42; LI, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/getelementptrinst">GetElementPtrInst</a> &#42; GEP, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/globalvariable">GlobalVariable</a> &#42; GV, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/cmpinst">CmpInst</a> &amp; ICI, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constantint">ConstantInt</a> &#42; AndCst=nullptr)</>}>
This is called when we see this pattern: cmp pred (load (gep GV, ...)), cmpcst where GV is a global variable with a constant initializer.

Try to simplify this into some simple computation that does not need the load. For example we can optimize &quot;icmp eq (load (gep &quot;foo&quot;, 0, i)), 0&quot; into &quot;icmp eq i, 3&quot;.

If AndCst is non-null, then the loaded value is masked with that constant before doing the comparison. This handles cases like &quot;A&#91;i&#93;&amp;4 == 0&quot;.

</MemberDefinition>

### foldOpIntoPhi() {#a2fc50d227d302eb98914f04bcc6634e1}

<MemberDefinition

### foldUsingDistributiveLaws() {#a2511e442d198696042ad2a39cad89059}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Value &#42; InstCombinerImpl::foldUsingDistributiveLaws (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/binaryoperator">BinaryOperator</a> &amp; I)</>}>
Tries to simplify binary operations which some other binary operation distributes over.

This tries to simplify binary operations which some other binary operation distributes over either by factorizing out common terms (eg &quot;(A&#42;B)+(A&#42;C)&quot; -&gt; &quot;A&#42;(B+C)&quot;) or expanding out if this results in simplifications (eg: &quot;A &amp; (B | C) -&gt; (A&amp;B) | (A&amp;C)&quot; if this is a win).

It does this by either by factorizing out common terms (eg &quot;(A&#42;B)+(A&#42;C)&quot; -&gt; &quot;A&#42;(B+C)&quot;) or expanding out if this results in simplifications (eg: &quot;A
&amp; (B | C) -&gt; (A&amp;B) | (A&amp;C)&quot; if this is a win). Returns the simplified value, or null if it didn&#39;t simplify.

Returns the simplified value, or null if it didn&#39;t simplify.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h/#l00506">506</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h">InstCombineInternal.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instructioncombining-cpp/#l01132">1132</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instructioncombining-cpp">InstructionCombining.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### prepareWorklist() {#a51dffbda74e47e34a64858d09d456108}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool InstCombinerImpl::prepareWorklist (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/function">Function</a> &amp; F)</>}>
Perform early cleanup and prepare the InstCombine worklist.

Populate the IC worklist from a function, by walking it in reverse post-order and adding all reachable code to the worklist.

This has a couple of tricks to make the code faster and more powerful. In particular, we constant fold and DCE instructions as we go, to avoid adding them to the worklist (this significantly speeds up instcombine on code where many instructions are dead or constant). Additionally, if we find a branch whose condition is a known constant, we only visit the reachable successors.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h/#l00076">76</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h">InstCombineInternal.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instructioncombining-cpp/#l05357">5357</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instructioncombining-cpp">InstructionCombining.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### replacedSelectWithOperand() {#af37433fe005d86f4551e44915bd97e0b}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool InstCombinerImpl::replacedSelectWithOperand (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/selectinst">SelectInst</a> &#42; SI, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/icmpinst">ICmpInst</a> &#42; Icmp, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> unsigned SIOpd)</>}>
Try to replace select with select operand SIOpd in SI-ICmp sequence.

True when a select result is replaced by one of its operands in select-icmp sequence.

This will eventually result in the elimination of the select.


<ParametersList title="Parameters">
<ParametersListItem name="<a href=&quot;/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/si&quot;>SI</a>">Select instruction</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="Icmp">Compare instruction</ParametersListItem>
<ParametersListItem name="SIOpd">Operand that replaces the select</ParametersListItem>
</ParametersList>
Notes:
<ul>
<li>The replacement is global and requires dominator information</li>
<li>The caller is responsible for the actual replacement</li>
</ul>


Example:

entry: %4 = select i1 %3, C&#42; %0, C&#42; null %5 = icmp eq C&#42; %4, null br i1 %5, label %9, label %7 ... ; &lt;label&gt;:7 ; preds = entry %8 = getelementptr inbounds C&#42; %4, i64 0, i32 0 ...

can be transformed to

%5 = icmp eq C&#42; %0, null %6 = select i1 %3, i1 %5, i1 true br i1 %6, label %9, label %7 ... ; &lt;label&gt;:7 ; preds = entry %8 = getelementptr inbounds C&#42; %0, i64 0, i32 0 // replace by %0!

Similar when the first operand of the select is a constant or/and the compare is for not equal rather than equal.

NOTE: The function is only called when the select and compare constants are equal, the optimization can work only for EQ predicates. This is not a major restriction since a NE compare should be &#39;normalized&#39; to an equal compare, which usually happens in the combiner and test case select-cmp-br.ll checks for it.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h/#l00194">194</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h">InstCombineInternal.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombinecompares-cpp/#l06617">6617</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombinecompares-cpp">InstCombineCompares.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### SimplifyAssociativeOrCommutative() {#a225d5b1dcc0015e743f1dbbf348a9c36}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool InstCombinerImpl::SimplifyAssociativeOrCommutative (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/binaryoperator">BinaryOperator</a> &amp; I)</>}>
Performs a few simplifications for operators which are associative or commutative.

This performs a few simplifications for operators that are associative or commutative:

Commutative operators:


<ul>
<li>Order operands such that they are listed from right (least complex) to left (most complex). This puts constants before unary operators before binary operators.</li>
</ul>


Associative operators:


<ul>
<li>Transform: &quot;(A op B) op C&quot; ==&gt; &quot;A op (B op C)&quot; if &quot;B op C&quot; simplifies.</li>
<li>Transform: &quot;A op (B op C)&quot; ==&gt; &quot;(A op B) op C&quot; if &quot;A op B&quot; simplifies.</li>
</ul>


Associative and commutative operators:


<ul>
<li>Transform: &quot;(A op B) op C&quot; ==&gt; &quot;(C op A) op B&quot; if &quot;C op A&quot; simplifies.</li>
<li>Transform: &quot;A op (B op C)&quot; ==&gt; &quot;B op (C op A)&quot; if &quot;C op A&quot; simplifies.</li>
<li>Transform: &quot;(A op C1) op (B op C2)&quot; ==&gt; &quot;(A op B) op (C1 op C2)&quot; if C1 and C2 are constants.</li>
</ul>

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h/#l00497">497</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h">InstCombineInternal.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instructioncombining-cpp/#l00428">428</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instructioncombining-cpp">InstructionCombining.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### SimplifyDemandedUseBits() {#a4bb2cbb88b57c9a126549efe2134d1cb}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Value &#42; InstCombinerImpl::SimplifyDemandedUseBits (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; I, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; DemandedMask, <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/knownbits">KnownBits</a> &amp; Known, unsigned Depth, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/simplifyquery">SimplifyQuery</a> &amp; Q)</>}>
Attempts to replace I with a simpler value based on the demanded bits.

This function attempts to replace V with a simpler value based on the demanded bits.

When this function is called, it is known that only the bits set in DemandedMask of the result of V are ever used downstream. Consequently, depending on the mask and V, it may be possible to replace V with a constant or one of its operands. In such cases, this function does the replacement and returns true. In all other cases, it returns false after analyzing the expression and setting KnownOne and known to be one in the expression. Known.Zero contains all the bits that are known to be zero in the expression. These are provided to potentially allow the caller (which might recursively be SimplifyDemandedBits itself) to simplify the expression. Known.One and Known.Zero always follow the invariant that: Known.One &amp; Known.Zero == 0. That is, a bit can&#39;t be both 1 and 0. The bits in Known.One and Known.Zero are accurate even for bits not in DemandedMask. Note also that the bitwidth of V, DemandedMask, Known.Zero and Known.One must all be the same.

This returns null if it did not change anything and it permits no simplification. This returns V itself if it did some simplification of V&#39;s operands based on the information about what bits are demanded. This returns some other non-null value if it found out that V is equal to another value in the context where the specified bits are demanded, but not for all users.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h/#l00551">551</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h">InstCombineInternal.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombinesimplifydemanded-cpp/#l00163">163</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombinesimplifydemanded-cpp">InstCombineSimplifyDemanded.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### SimplifyDemandedVectorElts() {#a37cce7aa1875173688e5971c5d6fa9e0}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Value &#42; InstCombinerImpl::SimplifyDemandedVectorElts (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; V, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> DemandedElts, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; PoisonElts, unsigned Depth=0, bool AllowMultipleUsers=false)</>}
  labels = {["virtual"]}>
The specified value produces a vector with any number of elements.

This method analyzes which elements of the operand are poison and returns that information in PoisonElts.

DemandedElts contains the set of elements that are actually used by the caller, and by default (AllowMultipleUsers equals false) the value is simplified only if it has a single caller. If AllowMultipleUsers is set to true, DemandedElts refers to the union of sets of elements that are used by all callers.

If the information about demanded elements can be used to simplify the operation, the operation is simplified, then the resultant value is returned. This returns null if no change was made.

### simplifyShrShlDemandedBits() {#a93a6fd2ea0b1d80347d4d5eff6462428}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Value &#42; InstCombinerImpl::simplifyShrShlDemandedBits (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; Shr, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; ShrOp1, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &#42; Shl, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; ShlOp1, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/apint">APInt</a> &amp; DemandedMask, <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/knownbits">KnownBits</a> &amp; Known)</>}>
Helper routine of SimplifyDemandedUseBits.

It tries to simplify demanded bit for &quot;r1 = shr x, c1; r2 = shl r1, c2&quot; instruction sequence.

It tries to simplify &quot;E1 = (X lsr C1) &lt;&lt; C2&quot;, where the C1 and C2 are constant, into &quot;E2 = X &lt;&lt; (C2 - C1)&quot; or &quot;E2 = X &gt;&gt; (C1 - C2)&quot;, depending on the sign of &quot;C2-C1&quot;.

Suppose E1 and E2 are generally different in bits S=&#123;bm, bm+1, ..., bn&#125;, without considering the specific value X is holding. This transformation is legal iff one of following conditions is hold: 1) All the bit in S are 0, in this case E1 == E2. 2) We don&#39;t care those bits in S, per the input DemandedMask. 3) Combination of 1) and 2). Some bits in S are 0, and we don&#39;t care the rest bits.

Currently we only test condition 2).

As with SimplifyDemandedUseBits, it returns NULL if the simplification was not successful.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h/#l00569">569</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h">InstCombineInternal.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombinesimplifydemanded-cpp/#l01321">1321</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombinesimplifydemanded-cpp">InstCombineSimplifyDemanded.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### SliceUpIllegalIntegerPHI() {#ac8cb4401526dd424f15566e4501792f7}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Instruction &#42; InstCombinerImpl::SliceUpIllegalIntegerPHI (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/phinode">PHINode</a> &amp; FirstPhi)</>}>
This is an integer PHI and we know that it has an illegal type: see if it is only used by trunc or trunc(lshr) operations.

If so, we split the PHI into the various pieces being extracted. This sort of thing is introduced when SROA promotes an aggregate to large integer values.

TODO: The user of the trunc may be an bitcast to float/double/vector or an inttoptr. We should produce new PHIs in the right type.

### takeLog2() {#a3bc72a9347951e36bc3a991d6bfc44ea}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Value &#42; InstCombinerImpl::takeLog2 (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; Op, unsigned Depth, bool AssumeNonZero, bool DoFold)</>}>
Take the exact integer log2 of the value.

If DoFold is true, create the actual instructions, otherwise return a non-null dummy value. Return nullptr on failure. Note, if DoFold is true the caller must ensure that takeLog2 will succeed, otherwise it may create stray instructions.

### visitInsertValueInst() {#a643f8d7ef849e1312c83906b4b27b4aa}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Instruction &#42; InstCombinerImpl::visitInsertValueInst (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/insertvalueinst">InsertValueInst</a> &amp; I)</>}>
Try to find redundant insertvalue instructions, like the following ones: %0 = insertvalue &#123; i8, i32 &#125; undef, i8 x, 0 %1 = insertvalue &#123; i8, i32 &#125; %0, i8 y, 0 Here the second instruction inserts values at the same indices, as the first one, making the first one redundant.

It should be transformed to: %0 = insertvalue &#123; i8, i32 &#125; undef, i8 y, 0

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h/#l00171">171</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h">InstCombineInternal.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombinevectorops-cpp/#l01214">1214</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombinevectorops-cpp">InstCombineVectorOps.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### canonicalizeConditionalNegationViaMathToSelect() {#a7507e8017bc0e90fcd0005847d2d4326}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Instruction &#42; InstCombinerImpl::canonicalizeConditionalNegationViaMathToSelect (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/binaryoperator">BinaryOperator</a> &amp; i)</>}>
Look for the pattern that conditionally negates a value via math operations: cond.splat = sext i1 cond sub = add cond.splat, x xor = xor sub, cond.splat and rewrite it to do the same, but via logical operations: value.neg = sub 0, value cond = select i1 neg, value.neg, value.

### foldAndOrOfICmpsUsingRanges() {#a20fcaac37809b21f2b99a2bb327f6a6b}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Value &#42; InstCombinerImpl::foldAndOrOfICmpsUsingRanges (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/icmpinst">ICmpInst</a> &#42; ICmp1, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/icmpinst">ICmpInst</a> &#42; ICmp2, bool IsAnd)</>}>
Fold (icmp Pred1 V1, C1) &amp; (icmp Pred2 V2, C2) or (icmp Pred1 V1, C1) | (icmp Pred2 V2, C2) into a single comparison using range-based reasoning.

NOTE: This is also used for logical and/or, must be poison-safe!

### foldEqOfParts() {#ace03e2c85229f4c56f346b8467608401}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Value &#42; InstCombinerImpl::foldEqOfParts (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; Cmp0, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; Cmp1, bool IsAnd)</>}>
(icmp eq X0, Y0) &amp; (icmp eq X1, Y1) -&gt; icmp eq X01, Y01 (icmp ne X0, Y0) | (icmp ne X1, Y1) -&gt; icmp ne X01, Y01 where X0, X1 and Y0, Y1 are adjacent parts extracted from an integer.

We have an expression of the form (A &amp; C) | (B &amp; D).

If A is a scalar or vector composed of all-zeros or all-ones values and is the bitwise &#39;not&#39; of B, it can be used as the condition operand of a select instruction. We will detect (A &amp; C) | ~(B | D) when the flag ABIsTheSame enabled.

### matchSelectFromAndOr() {#a390a2bb7f81ce9b36c11f67293a6df45}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Value &#42; InstCombinerImpl::matchSelectFromAndOr (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; A, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; B, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; C, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; D, bool InvertFalseVal=false)</>}>
We have an expression of the form (A &amp; B) | (C &amp; D).

Try to simplify this to &quot;A&#39; ? B : D&quot;, where A&#39; is a boolean or vector of booleans. When InvertFalseVal is set to true, we try to match the pattern where we have peeked through a &#39;not&#39; op and A and C are the same: (A &amp; B) | ~(A | D) --&gt; (A &amp; B) | (~A &amp; ~D) --&gt; A&#39; ? B : ~D

### narrowMathIfNoOverflow() {#a7366d46f4666e802c0b89985e121b97d}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Instruction &#42; InstCombinerImpl::narrowMathIfNoOverflow (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/binaryoperator">BinaryOperator</a> &amp; BO)</>}>
Try to narrow the width of a binop if at least 1 operand is an extend of of a value.

This requires a potentially expensive known bits check to make sure the narrow op does not overflow.

### optimizeBitCastFromPhi() {#ad5f238c0413f74ffb21220dbbf99ff4f}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>Instruction &#42; InstCombinerImpl::optimizeBitCastFromPhi (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/castinst">CastInst</a> &amp; CI, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/phinode">PHINode</a> &#42; PN)</>}>
This function handles following case.

<CodeBlock>
A  -&gt;  B    cast
PHI
B  -&gt;  A    cast
</CodeBlock>

All the related PHI nodes can be replaced by new PHI nodes with type A. The uses of <code>CI</code> can be changed to the new PHI node corresponding to <code>PN</code>.

### OptimizeOverflowCheck() {#aeb629aa76cd279921131f4ffca96707d}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool InstCombinerImpl::OptimizeOverflowCheck (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction/#ac26154a24f393f523c87cc5f8239f36c">Instruction::BinaryOps</a> BinaryOp, bool IsSigned, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; LHS, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42; RHS, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/instruction">Instruction</a> &amp; CtxI, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> &#42;&amp; OperationResult, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/constant">Constant</a> &#42;&amp; OverflowResult)</>}>
Try to optimize a sequence of instructions checking if an operation on LHS and RHS overflows.

If this overflow check is done via one of the overflow check intrinsics, then CtxI has to be the call instruction calling that intrinsic. If this overflow check is done by arithmetic followed by a compare, then CtxI has to be the arithmetic instruction.

If a simplification is possible, stores the simplified result of the operation in OperationResult and result of the overflow check in <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#a06c60fef11885eadbda4026c83ae9a13">OverflowResult</a>, and return true. If no simplification is possible, returns false.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h/#l00272">272</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h">InstCombineInternal.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombinecompares-cpp/#l06293">6293</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombinecompares-cpp">InstCombineCompares.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### shouldChangeType() {#a5cc3bea62cd8b99dcf0137786b846644}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype="bool InstCombinerImpl::shouldChangeType (unsigned FromWidth, unsigned ToWidth) const">
Return true if it is desirable to convert an integer computation from a given bit width to a new bit width.

We don&#39;t want to convert from a legal or desirable type (like i8) to an illegal type or from a smaller to a larger illegal type. A width of &#39;1&#39; is always treated as a desirable type because i1 is a fundamental type in IR, and there are many specialized optimizations for i1 types. Common/desirable widths are equally treated as legal to convert to, in order to open up more combining opportunities.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h/#l00245">245</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instcombineinternal-h">InstCombineInternal.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instructioncombining-cpp/#l00242">242</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/transforms/lib/transforms/instcombine/instructioncombining-cpp">InstructionCombining.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

Return true if it is desirable to convert a computation from &#39;From&#39; to &#39;To&#39;.

We don&#39;t want to convert from a legal to an illegal type or from a smaller to a larger illegal type. i1 is always treated as a legal type because it is a fundamental type in IR, and there are many specialized optimizations for i1 types.
